intro: Quercus wilsonii, commonly known as Wilson's oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its lobed leaves and acorn-producing capsules. The plant has a shallow root system and thrives in well-drained soils. Its foliage turns vibrant shades of red and yellow in the fall, contributing to its ornamental value. It plays a vital role in supporting local wildlife, providing food and shelter for various species.
